loans.use: to buy additional stock like noodles, snack food, biscuits, soda, rice and other items

loans.name: Evamie

texts.en:
Evamie is married and has one child. She is 26 years old and lives in Panduma Sr. Tukuran. To earn a living, Evamie has a business selling personal products, and she has had this business for two years. Each month, she earns 5,000 PHP doing this work. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP, to purchase new items, such as clothes and shoes, to resell. 

Evamie has been a member of GDMPC since 2011. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase new items, such as clothes and shoes, to resell

loans.name: Dioscora

texts.en:
Dioscora of Panduma, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur has been raising pigs for more than six years and earns 7,915 per month. She’s 33 years old now and continues to hang on with her pig-raising livelihood to provide an adequate life for her four children. 

She is a new member of GDMPC. In order to enhance her livestock for selling, she is borrowing the amount of 10,000 from GDMPC Microcredit to purchase feeding supplies. Dioscora hopes that someday, her children will be successful in their careers.

loans.use: to purchase feeding supplies

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie is a hard-working entrepreneur, who has a fishing business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 19,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fishing gear, including bamboo and other fishing equipment.

NWTF is again listing Melanie's business profile, for this new loan in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear, including bamboo and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with three children and all her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (her mother). She sells sweet potatoes and cassava at the market. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 6 years. She works seven days a week. She gets additional income from rental houses. 

She has requested for a loan of Uganda shillings 300,000 from MCDT – SACCO to buy bags of sweet potatoes and cassava. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to get more capital so as to sell other types of food stuffs. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sweet potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita of San Carlos, Tukuran helps her family through a fishing vending business. She’s 36 years old, married with 4 kids, and tries her best to make a living on her own. For 7 years, she has been managing this business and earns about 4,500 per month. For the time being, she’s in need of purchasing fishing equipment including hooks & nets. She joined in 2008 and thanks GDMPC micro finance for the loan of 3,000 they provided to her. Lolita desires to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Madjie

texts.en:
Madjie is 23 years old and married with one kid. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Madjie has a fishing business in the Philippines. Madjie requested a 14,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

She has been in this business for three years. In the future, Madjie would like to save enough to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita, 67, is a widow with four children. She is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She owns and operates a retail store at home to make a living. She's been running this business for 21 years now and earns about 3,200 PHP (Philippines pesos) a month. 

In 2008, Conchita joined Kiva's partner GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 to purchase new items such as candies, Milo, shampoo, soaps, etc. She dreams of a business expansion someday.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, Milo, shampoo, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Jeanalie

texts.en: Jeanalie is a new micro-finance member of PMPC.  She is 27 years old, married with three school-age children.  She lives in Tacloban, Siquijor, Siquijor.  She has been engaged in selling ready-to-wear clothes and pants for 2 years earning a monthly average of Php 2,000.  She decided to join PMPC to gain access to financial support for her business.  She took her first loan in PMPC in the amount of Php 5,000 to purchase clothes and pants for sale.  She plans to use the profits to save for the future of her children.

loans.use: to purchase clothes and pants for sale

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
Ethel works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Ethel requested a 14,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

She has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future, Ethel would like to save enough money to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Richel

texts.en: Richel is 32 years-old. She is married with 3 dependents. She live in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is cultivating rice to earn a living. For the past three years, every month, she has been getting a total of 6,000 from her work. Richel joined GDMPC in 2010. She has requested a loan of 10,000 to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Richel plans to plant as much as she can, to generate enough for the family and buy more lots to increase farm production.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane runs a sari-sari store (or convenience store) business in Talibon, Bohol. She has been in the business for more than six years now. This is her source of income necessary for the family expenses and needs.

Mary Jane wants a loan to buy more stock to sell, such as noodles, biscuits, soap and shampoo. Through this loan, May Jane will finally be able to augment her income through her sales.

In the future, May Jane wants to make her business a success.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell, such as noodles, biscuits, soap and shampoo.

loans.name: Topista's Group

texts.en:
Topista's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Topista is 22 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past three years, Topista has been working hard to manage her small hotel (a term for a primitive restaurant), which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Topista has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more fresh food like matooke (green plantains) and Irish potatoes and some dry food like maize flour for cooking in the hotel for resale. The loan will help Topista to generate greater profits and pay for medical bills for her mother and buy new clothes for herself. Topista hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a big good house and drive a car. 

Topista is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh food like matooke (green plantains) and Irish potatoes and some dry food like maize flour for cooking in the hotel for resale.

loans.name: Imara

texts.en: Imara is one of the few old women who do not want to fully depend on their spouses for their daily needs. This is the motivation that drives her to continue being in business. For several years, she has been operating a grocery store which has provided her commendable results. Today, she is asking for a new loan to invest in her food stall which she opened recently. With this loan, she plans to buy ingredients like meat, maize flour, vegetables, rice, beans, among other ingredients.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like meat, maize flour, vegetables, rice, beans, among other ingredients.

loans.name: Daninova

texts.en:
Daninova is 64 years old and married with four children.

Daninova works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (convenience) store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery items like bread, soft drinks, sardines and other groceries.

Daninova has been in this business for six years and has previously received funds through Kiva. She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items like bread, soft drinks, sardines and other groceries.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy is a 36-year-old man and is married to Noni, a 32-year-old woman. They are blessed with 4 children:  
•	Paula, 13, is attending 2nd grade of junior high school
•	Grace, 12, is attending 1st grade of junior high school
•	Leo, 11, is attending 5th grade of elementary school
•	Sandi, 10, is attending 4th  grade of elementary school

Teddy is an employee but he also runs a business of photo editing and printing as well as document printing. He usually operates the business after work. 

Teddy has many customers so he is able to earn more income for his family. Recently, his printing machine and computer were damaged so he needs money to repair them. Therefore, Teddy submitted a loan application to TLM and requested a loan of IDR 4,500,000. The loan would help him to repair the printing machine, computer and to purchase more paper and ink.

loans.use: to repair the printing machine, computer and to purchase more paper and ink.

loans.name: Ma. Azucena

texts.en:
Ma. Azucena is 57 years old and is married with five children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. She has been in this business for 4 years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Ma. Azucena aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Vernecita

texts.en:
Vernecita is a 25-year-old married woman and a mother of a two-year-old child. She is from Bien Unido, Bohol. She is in the hog raising business.
Vernecita needs a loan to buy additional piglets to raise and to buy feed for the pigs. Through this, she will be able to raise healthy pigs.
In the future, Vernecita dreams of improving her business and saving money for the schooling of her daughter.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets to raise and to buy feed for the pigs

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Bernadita works hard to support her family.

She has a charcoal sales business in the Philippines. Bernadita is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to buy more stock of charcoal to sell to her customers.

Bernadita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell to customers.

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn is a 21-year-old married woman from Cortes,Bohol. She has two children ages two and seven months old. 

She has been in the sari-sari (variety) store business for one year. She sells commodities like flour, sugar, catsup, salt, canned goods, shampoo, toiletries, and soap. 

She has requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchased additional groceries to sell like flour, canned goods, and soft drinks. Jenelyn would like to expand her business by investing other ventures in order to save and at the same time earn for her children's future.

loans.use: to buy merchandise like flour, canned goods, and soft drinks

loans.name: Olivia's Group

texts.en:
Olivia's group is comprised of 3 hard working women. Olivia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fortportal region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Olivia has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells soft drinks like soda and passion fruit juice. 

To help expand her business, Olivia has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda (a portion of the group's total loan amount). The loan will be used to buy more soft drinks like sodas for resale, and will help Olivia to generate greater profits and pay for her medical bills. Olivia hopes that in the future she will be able to build a permanent house for her self. 

Olivia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks like sodas for resale

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.en:
Edgardo is an active member of PMPC.  He is 48 years old, separated, and a resident of Banban, Siquijor, Siquijor.  He has been engaged in the grocery store business for 2 years with an average monthly income of PHP 1,500.  

He has taken another loan from PMPC in the amount of PHP 9,000 to purchase additional grocery stocks for sale hoping to increase his volume of sales and increase his income to save for his future.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery stock for sale.

loans.name: Thaer

texts.en: Thaer is 38 years old, married, and has one child. He has worked as a taxi driver since 2006. Just like most Palestinians in Lebanon, Thaer does not have many options for work. Because of this, he rented a car which he is working on and uses as a taxi to provide for his family and improve their standard of living. Thaer used to work as a mechanic but he was not making enough money to cover his expenses. Thaer has been an Al Majmoua borrower for five cycles. He believes that Al Majmoua is the only one supporting him and standing next to the Palestinians in Lebanon. His previous loans helped improve his standard of living a lot. The present requested loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua will be used to do necessary maintenance on his car, which is his only source of income. Thaer hopes to reopen his garage one day and work as a mechanic again because he loves that business a lot.

loans.use: to do necessary maintenance on a car

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita is a micro-finance member of PMPC. She is 61 years old and is married with six adult-age children. 

She has engaged in making and selling snacks for 3 years with a weekly average income of PHP 400. She took another loan with PMPC to purchase additional raw ingredients to make snacks. She plans to use the profit to provide for her family's needs and to invest additional capital into the business.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw ingredients to make snacks.

loans.name: Nemesia

texts.en:
Nemesia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an abaca weaving business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase fiber for her abaca weaving business.

NWTF is relisting Nemesia's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase abaca fiber for her abaca weaving business.

loans.name: Vernilyn

texts.en:
Vernilyn runs an eatery in her place in Getafe, Bohol, Philippines. She has been in this business for more than 5 years now. 

Vernilyn is asking for a loan to buy additional ingredients for her food vending business such as meat, vegetables, seasonings, and other items. With this loan, she will be able to cater to more customers in her eatery and will be able to increase her income.

In the future, Vernilyn dreams of expanding her food vending business and saving money for the education of her 8-year-old son.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her food vending business such as meat, vegetables, seasonings, and other items.

loans.name: Jenny Fe

texts.en:
Jenny Fe works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business selling flowers in the Philippines.

Jenny Fe requested a PHP 24,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer for her flowers. She has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Jenny Fe would like to save enough money to buy a motorcycle for her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her flowers.

loans.name: Julieto

texts.en:
Julieto is a 60-year-old married man and has been engaged in the tricycle transport business for several years now. This is the source of his income. He lives in Talibon, Bohol. Julieto works hard to support the needs of his family. 

Julieto is asking for a loan to buy fuel and spare parts for his tricycle. He believes that this loan could be a great help for him in improving his livelihood. In the future, Julieto hopes to make his business a success.

loans.use: to buy fuel and spare parts for his tricycle.

loans.name: Davaadorj

texts.en:
Davaadorj is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. His wife's name is Toihorol. She is 32 years old and unemployed. His older son goes to secondary school. His younger son goes to kindergarten. 

Davaadorj started a shoe repair business in 1998. He is experienced in this business. He has his own workplace for shoe repair. But the shoe repair business cannot make enough money to cover all the expenses for his family. 

Davaadorj decided to operate a transportation business and needed a suitable truck to provide transportation. He is a hardworking, optimistic, and diligent man. He is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase a suitable vehicle to provide transportation service. He says "I want to maximize my profit to save for my children's future education".

loans.use: to purchase a suitable vehicle to provide transportation service.

loans.name: Las Perlas Group

texts.es:
Las Perlas se denomina llama el grupo que está integrado por 17 mujeres de la ciudad de Itá. Gracias al trabajo que todas hacen, ya están en su ciclo numero 16. Una de estas mujeres es la Sra. Acela, quien también es la presidenta del grupo, ella se dedica a la venta de prendas y de calzados.
Comenta que al principio le costó salir adelante, pero que después fue afianzándose y hoy en día ya tiene una buena clientela.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de calzados y prendas para la venta.
texts.en:
“Las Perlas" (The Pearls) is the name of this group that consists of 17 women from the city of Itá. Thanks to the work all of them have accomplished, they have now reached their 16th loan cycle.

One of these women is Sra. Acela, who also serves as the group president. She sells clothing and shoes. Acela says that she struggled to get ahead at first, but she later established herself and now has a good clientele. She is requesting a loan in order to buy shoes and clothing to sell.

loans.use: to buy shoes and clothing.
